newsitem.title: UK: North Sea wet Brent trade active, Med cautious.
newsitem.headline: North Sea wet Brent trade active, Med cautious.

text.p: At least four wet Brent cargoes traded at steady levels on Tuesday, but a rumoured late trade at a firmer level and the keeping of today's sole Brent date gave the market a firmer tone later.

Physical Brents were confirmed done at March Brent +28 cents a barrel for a Feb 12-14 cargo, March +30 cents for a Feb 18-20 cargo, at March +27 cents for a Feb 17-19 loader and on a dated-related basis for another Feb 17-19.
A Feb 18-20 cargo clocked to a trading house on Monday was widely heard to be been sold on a Dated-related basis, and then rumoured to have been resold to a refiner as high as March +35.
The sole cargo nominated from the paper chains on Tuesday was kept by BP.
"There's a lot of misleading talk around, but overall it's definitely looking a stronger market than yesterday," a trader said.
Other North Sea grades were quiet. A Statfjord was heard on offer at Dated Brent +55 cents, after a cargo loading Feb 27-March 1 traded at Dated Brent +53 cents late on Monday.
Brent intermonth spreads were steady to slightly firmer. March/April was done at +44 and +45 cents, while April/May was talked at +39/45 cents.
Brent CFDs also moved higher, with this week's dates traded at March Brent +28 cents, and next week's at March +15 cents.
In the Mediterranean, the Urals market looked notionally weaker after one local refiner said that it had cut crude runs and others also complained of dismal margins.

At least three small Urals cargoes loading around the end of the first decade and a large second decade cargo were seen available, but sellers were reluctant to put price tags to their cargoes, traders said.
"No-one is showing prices," said one trader.
